bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Reference Librarian, Congressional Library, January 29, 1941

div1.p: Hench asks the reference librarian about the availability of material pertaining to the work of the U.S. Army Yellow Fever Commission in 1900.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Reference Librarian, Congressional Library, January 29, 1941
div1.opener:
Sen for 822

January 29, 1941
Reference Librarian
Congressional Library
Washington, D. C.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
I have been asked by the Minister of National Defense of the Cuban
government to assist in the establishment of the true identity of the sites
used by the U. S. Army Yellow Commission (Drs. Walter Reed, James Carroll,
Aristodes Agramonte, and Jesse Lazear) in 1900, during the experiments which
successfully identified the cause of yellow fever. I would greatly appreciate
your help in obtaining data I have been unable to obtain elsewhere. Before
deciding to bother you with this request, I assure you I have spent much time
in the libraries of Rochester, Minneapolis, Chicago and New York.

list.item:
1. Is the material in your library available on microfilm or bibliofilm?
If so, at what cost, and how may I order it?

2. Can material also be obtained in photoprint or photostat form? If so
at what cost?

3. Can I get bibliofilm or photostats of articles in American magazines
around 1900 to 1910?

4. What Havana, Cuba newspapers and news magazines do you have, covering
the period between July, 1900 and March, 1901?

5. Do you lend books to other libraries. Could I borrow though inter-
library loan (to the Mayo Clinic library) the following three books: (a) U. S.
Adjutant General's Office, Cuban Division, Havana Department; annual report of
the commanding general, 1899; (b) Same for 1900; (c) Same for 1901. These books
are sometimes entitled Headquarters Department of Cuba: Office of the Adjutant
General; Annual report for etc...

6. How could I obtain bibliofilm or photostat copies of articles (all
pertaining to the work on the above mentioned U. S. Army physicians) in the follow-
ing newspapers of Havana:
(a) Unidentified Havana newspaper of Sept. 25 and Sept. 29, 1900,
commenting on the death of Dr. Lazear, and the illness of Dr.
Carroll. In a letter to his wife dated Sept. 25 or 28, Dr.
Carroll wrote "There was quite a notice in this morning's paper
about Dr. Lazear (who died Sept. 25, 1900) and your husband is
mentioned too.
Not in
Kean de la Moran
(b) Havana newspaper La Discusion for Nov. 21, 1900: article violently
criticizing the work of the U.S. Yellow Fever Board.
(c) Havana Post for November 24, 1900: comments on the work of the
Yellow Fever Board.
(d) Havana Post for November 25, 1900; comments on impending Pan-American
Medical Congress to be held in Havana.
(e) Unidentified Havana newspaper (possibly La Lucha, La Marina or the
Havana Post) for December 23, 1900, telling of the banquet the night
before (Dec. 22) honoring Dr. Carlos Finlay of Havana as the discoverer
of the mosquito theory of yellow fever.
not knows
de la Moran
(f) Havana Post, probably on or about Jan. 30, 1901. Dr. Carroll wrote
to his wife Jan. 31, 1901, speaking of a very sarcastic editorial in
the Havana Post, concerning the yellow fever work.
(g) Havana Post, for Jan. 31, 1901. Comments on the work of the U.S.
Army Yellow Fever Board.
(h) Havana newspapers for February 5 and 6, 1901, telling of Major
Walter Reed's announcement on Feb. 5, of the cause of yellow fever,
before the Third Pan-American Medical Congress in Havana.

div1.p:
If you do not have these papers available in your library, do you have any
idea where I might find them? They are not in the public libraries of New York,
Chicago, or Minneapolis. Last Spring, I visited the National Library in Havana,
to try to find these papers but strange to relate, they were packed away in boxes
unindexed, unidentified, and unavailable. I cannot tell you how grateful I will
be for whatever help you can give me. I enclose a stamped envelope for reply
and will promptly remit whatever charges there may be for photostating the above
items.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
